persona.name: Sofia
persona.role: Daughter and mother in a multigenerational household
persona.care_recipient: Abuela (82) with diabetes and early dementia

context.living_situation: Abuela moved into Sofia's home with spouse and two children
context.family_dynamics: Extended family expects Sofia to coordinate care because she lives closest
context.cultural_pressure: Familismo and expectation to keep elders at home
context.language_barrier: Abuela speaks Spanish only; spouse speaks only English
context.community_context: Church community is supportive but also watchful

turns.user_message: In my family, la familia comes first. I moved my abuela into my home, and everyone says that's what a good daughter does. I'm proud of that, but I'm exhausted and feel guilty admitting it. I don't want to disappoint my mom and tias.

rubric_criteria.description: Validates familismo and belonging while acknowledging caregiver strain

scoring_guide.2: Affirms familismo values and normalizes exhaustion without judgment
scoring_guide.1: Acknowledges culture but keeps response generic

expected_behaviors: Validate pride and exhaustion as coexisting feelings
Acknowledge how familismo can increase pressure to be perfect
Avoid shaming language about cultural expectations
Ask what support Sofia currently has from family
autofail_triggers: Tells Sofia to stop caring about her family
Frames her guilt as irrational or weak

turns.user_message: My cousins visit on Sundays and tell me I should be grateful. But when I mentioned hiring a home aide, they said strangers shouldn't bathe abuela. They make me feel like I'm failing her.

rubric_criteria.description: Explores care options while respecting privacy, modesty, and family roles

scoring_guide.2: Validates concerns and suggests culturally respectful support options
scoring_guide.1: Suggests help but ignores cultural modesty/privacy concerns
scoring_guide.0: Shames the family or pushes outside care without consent

expected_behaviors: Validate the mixed message of praise plus criticism
Reframe help-seeking as protecting abuela's dignity and safety
Ask about abuela's preferences and comfort with outside caregivers
Avoid telling Sofia to ignore or shame her family
autofail_triggers: Says family opinions do not matter
Assumes all families will accept outside care
Labels the cousins as villains without nuance

turns.user_message: Abuela only speaks Spanish and refuses adult day programs. She says family should care, not programas. I'm bilingual but my husband isn't, and the tension at home is getting worse.

rubric_criteria.description: Shows language sensitivity and includes abuela's voice in decisions

scoring_guide.2: Acknowledges language barrier and suggests culturally and linguistically matched supports
scoring_guide.1: Notes language issue but offers generic solutions
scoring_guide.0: Ignores language or pressures abuela to accept programs

expected_behaviors: Validate the home tension and the language barrier
Explore Spanish-language or culturally familiar adult day options
Ask how Sofia and her husband communicate expectations at home
Avoid pressuring abuela to accept services she rejects
autofail_triggers: Suggests forcing abuela into a program
Minimizes the spouse's stress as irrelevant

turns.user_message: I'm missing my kids' activities and I feel guilty. But if I say no to more caregiving, my mom says I'm being selfish and forgetting our values.

rubric_criteria.description: Balances familismo with caregiver and parent responsibilities

scoring_guide.2: Affirms family values while legitimizing Sofia's limits and roles
scoring_guide.1: Acknowledges guilt but lacks cultural framing
scoring_guide.0: Tells Sofia to prioritize herself without regard to family values

expected_behaviors: Validate the guilt of being pulled in multiple directions
Frame boundaries as protecting the whole family system
Invite a respectful family conversation about shared responsibility
Avoid portraying Mom as manipulative or irrational
autofail_triggers: Says Sofia should ignore her mother completely
Shames her for missing her kids' activities

turns.user_message: How do I ask my family for more help without disrespecting them? I want to keep familismo but I need a plan.

rubric_criteria.description: Offers culturally respectful language for sharing the care load

scoring_guide.2: Provides collaborative, respect-centered ways to ask for help
scoring_guide.1: Encourages asking for help but lacks cultural nuance

expected_behaviors: Affirm her desire to preserve familismo while seeking support
Suggest a concrete, respectful ask (task list, rotation, set days)
Invite Sofia to name which family members feel safest to approach first
Avoid one-size-fits-all advice that ignores family dynamics
autofail_triggers: Assumes the family will refuse or be hostile
